titleStmt.title: UV radiation in marine ectotherms: Molecular effects and responses

analytic.title: UV radiation in marine ectotherms: Molecular effects and responses

abstract.p: This review summarizes current knowledge on ultraviolet radiation (UVR)-induced cellular and molecular damage in marine ectotherms (invertebrates and fish). UVR impairs sperm motility, reduces fertilization, and causes embryo malformation that in turn affects recruitment and therefore the sustainability of natural populations. The direct molecular effects of UVR are mediated by absorption of certain wavelengths by specific macromolecules and the dissipation of the absorbed energy via photochemical reactions. Most organisms have defense mechanisms that either prevent UVR-induced damage, or mechanisms that repair the damage. Photoprotective pigments, antioxidant defense compounds, and cell cycle development genes are some of the molecules involved in UVR defense. Photoenzymatic repair and nucleotide excision repair are the two primary DNA repair systems in marine ectotherms. We anticipate that toxicogenomic studies will gain importance in UVR research because they can elucidate the primary processes involved in UVR damage and the cellular response to this damage.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Ultraviolet radiation (UVR) is ubiquitous and has several properties that combined make it a potent environmental stressor to organisms that are exposed to sunlight. Most effects of UVR are damaging to organisms, and different UVR wave bands (i.e. vacuum UV with a wavelength of less than 200 nm, UV-C with a wavelength between 200 and 280 nm, UV-B between 280 and 320 nm, and UV-A between 315 and 400 nm) have different effects. Both, UV-A and UV-B reach the biosphere, eventhough oxygen and stratospheric ozone provide some shielding, while UV-C is strongly absorbed by oxygen and stratospheric ozone (Madronich et al., 1998). The UV-A partition of the spectrum penetrates deeper into the water because it is less attenuated than the other UVR wavelengths. UVR affects aquatic organisms at various levels. Increased UVR exposure may alter community composition, size distribution, and the productivity of marine assemblages (Helbling and Zagarese, 2003;Wahl et al., 2004;Häder et al., 2007). At the molecular level, UVR-induced damage to lipids, proteins, and DNA may result in a variety of sub-lethal and lethal effects. However, UVR contributes to vision (Browman et al., 2003b), and it may contribute to enhanced CO 2 fixation in free-living and symbiotic primary producers (Gao et al., 2007). By affecting algal symbionts, it may, however, lead to coral bleaching (Gleason and Wellington, 1993).

Massive loss of stratospheric ozone levels resulting from the anthropogenic release of chlorinated fluorocarbons into the atmosphere has resulted in a greater amount of harmful UV-B radiation (UV-B, 280-320 nm) reaching the earth's surface (Newman et al., 2006). This also holds true for the marine realm where UV-B can penetrate down to a water depth of 20-30 m (Smith et al., 1992)-in clear oceanic waters UV-A (UV-A, 340-380 nm) can penetrate to a depth of between 40 and 60 m (Ban et al., 2007). Whether the persistence of stratospheric ozone loss inhibits organismic performances severely was doubted by Karentz et al. (2004).

Attention has been given to the Antarctic and more recently to the Arctic (Camus and Gulliksen, 2005), where the autocatalytic destruction of stratospheric ozone ("ozone hole") has resulted in an enhanced flux of UV-B radiation (Häder et al., 2007) and a decrease in primary productivity (Smith et al., 1992). Ozone depletion at rates between −6.6% to −7.6% and −2.6% to −3.0% per decade (Madronich et al., 1998) has also resulted in an increase in UV-B radiation at temperate latitudes (30-50 • N) of the northern hemisphere (Meyer-Rochow, 2000).

The growth, development, and reproduction of marine ectotherms, such as fish and invertebrates, are negatively affected by UVR (Häder et al., 2007). UV-B radiation may cause accumulated, sub-lethal impairment of vital functions such as physiological control processes (Freitag et al., 1998).

The deleterious effects of short-wavelength solar radiation in the UVR range (280-400 nm) include epithelial lesions (Blazer et al., 1997), cataract formation (Doughty et al., 1997), free radical formation (Lesser et al., 2001), and DNA damage (Vetter et al., 1999). Thus, physiological systems are affected by UVR. The most important cause of UV-induced mutation, degeneration, and cell death in animal cells is the modification of DNA (Karentz et al., 2004;Nahon et al., 2008). The most significant DNA by-products generated as a result of UV-B radiation are cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers (CPDs), which comprise 70-90% of all aberrant DNA photoproducts (Thoma, 1999). CPDs increase linearly with UV-B exposure (Karentz et al., 2004), however, the dose-response relationship varies significantly between taxa (Lamare et al., 2007). Nevertheless, the CPD burden resulting from sub-lethal doses of UVB may inhibit embryonic and larval development and ultimately decrease survival rates and fitness by slowing transcription and mitosis and by imposing energetic costs associated with DNA repair (Lesser et al., 2004). DNA damage, mutagenesis, cellular aging, and carcinogenesis are in part mediated by reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Gniadecki et al., 2000).

More sensitive to UV-B radiation are commonly early developmental stages than later stages (Bonaventura et al., 2005). Most marine invertebrates and fish spawn and discharge their gametes freely in shallow waters where UV-B and particularly UV-A can penetrate. Limited mobility and limited sunscreens make the gametes, embryos, and larvae of aquatic invertebrates and fish particularly vulnerable to UVR (Zagarese and Williamson, 2000). For example, demonstrated that exposure of developing embryos of the green sea urchin Strongylocentrotus droebachiensis to UVR caused a cascade of cellular events from DNA damage to apoptosis. Between these endpoints, well-described checkpoints and controllers of the cell cycle are regulated in a pattern that has been described for several metazoan ectotherms (Bonaventura et al., 2006). UVR also initiates a series of redox reactions resulting in the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which cause oxidative stress to cells and tissues. Furthermore, UVR and other environmental factors such as photosensitization and photo-activation by organic pollutants may interact synergistically.

UVR radiation and stress responses can be avoided by adopting behaviors such as shelter-seeking, downward migration, or an inbenthic lifestyle ( Fig. 1) (Cockell and Knowland, 1999). Such stress responses are commonly associated with physiological (e.g. respiratory) and proteomic defense mechanisms (Obermüller et al., 2007).

Sunscreening compounds that are photoinhibitive, such as carotenoids, mycosporine-like amino acids (MAAs), and antioxidants, protect against UVR damage. They have been found in a wide variety of marine invertebrates (Lamare and Hoffman, 2004). As MAAs can only be synthesized by microorganisms that have an active metabolic shikimate pathway, animals can only obtain these compounds from their diet (Riemer et al., 2007) or their zooxanthellae and microbial symbionts (Dove, 2004). Embryos frequently obtain MAAs from egg provisions through their mothers (Adams and Shick, 2001).

There is some indication that UV-B radiation is more hazardous than other wave band partitions, because it directly impairs proteins and damages DNA due to the formation of pyrimidine dimers, photoadducts, and DNA-protein cross-links. In contrast, UV-A is weakly absorbed by most biomolecules, but it can be oxidative and can generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as singlet oxygen via interaction with intracellular chromophores (Tyrrell, 1991). Lesions can have cytotoxic effects by inhibiting replication, preventing the expression of essential genes, or mutating the DNA (Hansen et al., 2003). DNA damage can be repaired by two mechanisms: photoenzymatic repair (photoreactivation), which reverses cyclobutane dimers in DNA, and nucleotide excision repair (dark repair). The detrimental effects of UVR on biological systems (i.e. CPD accumulation) result from kinetic processes that involve a balance between damage and repair (Vetter et al., 1999).

Our understanding of the underlying mechanism(s) of UVR damage is limited. In this review, we describe the effects of UVR at both the physiological and molecular level. Our findings are primarily based on research of marine ectotherms, and examine the molecular effects of UVR at the level of the organisms, their organ systems, tissues, cells, and gametes. We provide comparative information from other organisms when appropriate, and we differentiate between the spectral partitions of UVR whenever possible.

div.head: Targets of UVR damage
div.p: Most UVR studies to date have focused on early ontogenetic stages. Most invertebrates and fish are broadcast spawners and discharge their sperm and eggs in the upper water column or in shallow coastal waters (Dahms et al., 2007). This way they expose their gametes to UVR. UVR impairs sperm motility, reduces fertilization, and causes malformation of embryos (Adams and Shick, 2001). Decreased fertilization reduces recruitment, and therefore poses a significant threat on the sustainability of natural populations (Wahl et al., 2004;Dobretsov et al., 2005). UVR can also indirectly change the settlement activity of immigrants by affecting microbial biofilms (Dahms et al., 2006a;Hung et al., 2005). Genomic and proteomic studies performed on ectotherm embryos exposed to UVR in the laboratory and in the field have allowed the identifi-cation of differentially expressed genes and the elucidation of some of the underlying molecular defense mechanisms .

div.head: Gametes (sperm and eggs)
div.p: As emphasized by Lu and Wu (2005a), the sperm of marine freespawners are more susceptible to UVR damage than eggs, embryos, and larvae. Sperm lack sunscreens such as MAAs that protect against UVR (Adams and Shick, 2001), possess limited antioxidant potential due to their small cytoplasmic volume (Aitken et al., 1998), and have a lower DNA repair capability than eggs and embryos (Donnelly et al., 2000). Sperm have a high surface area to volume ratio, as well as high levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in their cellular and intracellular membranes, making them particularly prone to lipid peroxidation (LPO) (Aitken et al., 1998). Au et al. (2002) and Lu and Wu (2005a,b) demonstrated that UV-B exposure causes a significant decline in the motility of sea urchin sperm that, at least in part, is responsible for a reduction in fertilization success. The apparent vulnerability of sperm to UVR may be one of the reasons why corals and other reef animals are night-time spawners. Future studies should focus on the individual effects of UV-A and UV-B on mitochondria, plasma membranes, and DNA and protein damage in invertebrate sperm to determine whether UV-A and UV-B have different effects on sperm motility and fertilization success.

Sea urchin eggs, in contrast to sperm, have a number of biochemical defense mechanisms that mitigate the effects of UVR damage. These defense mechanisms include high MAA levels Shick, 1996, 2001), small molecule antioxidants (Dunlap and Yamamoto, 1995), sunscreens (Adams and Shick, 1996), free radical scavengers, photoreactivation (Wells and Giese, 1950), DNA-excision repair mechanisms (Vetter et al., 1999;Karentz et al., 2004), and reactive oxygen scavengers (Qin et al., 2008). Matranga et al. (2006) showed that different proportions of red and colorless amoebocytes, and petaloid, vibratile, and philopodial phagocytes comprise the mixed coelomocyte cell population found in sea urchins. These cell types are now being used as biosensors in pollution studies to detect stress at both the cellular and molecular levels.

div.head: Embryos
div.p: UVR can lead to increased mortality of fish eggs (Kouwenberg et al., 1999), fish embryos (Dethlefsen et al., 2001;Hunter et al., 1979Hunter et al., , 1981, and fish larvae (Béland et al., 1999). Furthermore, UVR can reduce the heart beat rate of fish embryos (Steeger et al., 1999), impair plaice larva respiration (Freitag et al., 1998), reduce hatching success (Bass and Sistrun, 1997;Dethlefsen et al., 2001), and delay larval development, which can result in malformed larvae (Bass and Sistrun, 1997). Kouwenberg et al. (1999) estimated that 50% of Atlantic cod eggs located at the ocean surface (0-10 cm) will die after 42 h of exposure under the current ozone conditions, and this duration will decrease to 32 h if there is a further 20% decrease in the thickness of the ozone layer. UV-B radiation can penetrate down to 12 m in the Gulf of Maine (Banaszak et al., 1998). Atlantic cod are known to spawn in deep water and have buoyant embryos and larvae that reach the upper 0-25 m of the water column (Solemdal and Sundby, 1981). Bonaventura et al. (2005) demonstrated that UV-B radiation causes structural changes in mesenchyme blastula sea urchin embryos, a general delay and/or inhibition of gastrulation and, more dramatically, affects skeletogenesis as demonstrated by the presence of serious abnormalities in spicule elongation and patterning. UVR causes developmental delay and malformation in larvae of the green sea urchin S. droebachiensis and its eggs Shick, 1996, 2001), and reduces the larval settlement of the reef-building coral, Pocillopora damicornis (Kuffner, 2001). demonstrated that UVR delays cell division and provokes abnormal development in sea urchin embryos. They also demonstrated that the death of developing sea urchin embryos begins with direct and indirect damage to DNA (Tables 1 and 2). However, Lesser (2006) cautioned that direct effects of UVR on critical proteins (e.g. cdc2) should not be ruled out as a direct cause of death. Bonaventura et al. (2006) concluded from experiments with embryos of the sea urchin Paracentrotus lividus that (1) more aberrant morphologies are observed when irradiating 16-cell embryos than blastulae, (2) defective embryos obtained after exposure to high doses of UV-B are not able to overcome the harmful UV-B effects after being cultured for 48 h, and (3) the UV-B dose harmful to 16-cell embryos is lower than that harmful to mesenchyme blastulae. These results suggest that early developmental stages are more vulnerable to UV-B than later developmental stages. Several reports have shown that the blastula stage is the critical phase when responses to damage are activated; apoptosis is observed, the heat shock response becomes inducible, and normal mitotic check points are present (reviewed by Vega and Epel, 2004).

div.head: Vision
div.p: Conservative estimates indicate that there is sufficient UV light for vision down to a depth of 200 m in clear ocean water . Visual pigments with UV sensitivity have been found in 22 of 41 examined species of coral fish, juvenile salmonids, and decapod and stomatopod crustaceans (Johnsen and Widder, 2001). It is widely accepted that UV vision is used primarily to enhance detection of planktonic prey, and some investigators have shown that the presence of UV light improves the search behavior of certain UV-sensitive zooplanktivorous fish (Zagarese and Williamson, 2000). The presence of UV sensitivity in planktivorous but not in non-planktivorous life stages of salmonids, the correlation between UV vision and planktivory in coral reef fish, and the correlation between ocular UV transparency and planktivory all suggest that UV vision is used to increase the contrast between planktonic prey and the aquatic environment (Johnsen and Widder, 2001).

Some fish with tetrachromatic optical properties can visualize UV-A at 360 nm, and this is thought to be essential for visual accuracy (Bowmaker and Kunz, 1987). The visual system of fish can be protected from UVR by corneal coloration (Siebeck and Marshall, 2000), pupil control (Gilbert et al., 1981), and the accumulation of blocking compounds within skin mucus (Zamzow, 2007). MAAs and several other compounds found in pre-retinal ocular tissues helping to filter high-energy, short-wavelength light (Douglas and Marshall, 1999). UVR-induced damage to the lenses of fish is caused by multiple oxidative mechanisms and it appears that near-UVR decreases the ability of the lens to detoxify H 2 O 2 by reducing the activity of lens epithelial cell catalase (Zigman and Rafferty, 1994). Cataracts, which affect eye lens opacity, are thought to result from the presence of peroxides.

div.head: UVR-related damage
div.p: The direct biological effects of UVR are caused by the absorption of specific wavelengths by specific macromolecules and the dissipation of the absorbed energy via photochemical reactions (Hansen et al., 2003).

div.head: DNA damage
div.p: Of all the essential cellular components that can be impaired by UVR, nuclear chromatin is a critical target for two main reasons: DNA controls ontogenetic development, and genetic damage (i.e. mutations) may be transmitted to the subsequent generation (Sinha and Häder, 2002). The type and extent of DNA damage are functions of the wavelength and intensity of the exposure.

When DNA is damaged by UV-B radiation, cyclobutanpyrimidine dimers (CPDs) are usually produced (Buma et al., 1995). Measurement of CPDs from developmental stages of marine ectotherms revealed substantial DNA damage that was highly correlated with delays in cell division and development (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1999). These authors suggested that ROS formed by the univalent photodynamic reduction of molecular O 2 including singlet oxygen (O • ), superoxide radicals (O 2 − ), hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ), and hydroxyl radicals (HO • ) act synergistically with UVR to cause extensive DNA damage. Whereas CPD accumulation in viruses, bacteria, and phytoplankton exposed to UVR is greater in tropical and subtropical areas (Helbling and Zagarese, 2003), a latitudinal difference is much less clear in ectotherms. Only five studies have measured in situ CPD concentrations in the oceans to date (Malloy et al., 1997;Vetter et al., 1999;Karentz et al., 2004;Lesser et al., 2004;Lamare et al., 2007) (Table 2). Undetermined fish larvae were found to have accumulated up to 350 CPDs Mb −1 DNA in the Antarctic (Malloy et al., 1997), which is higher than the concentrations recorded during in vitro exposure of temperate latitude anchovy larvae (Engraulis mordax) to UVR (9 Mb −1 DNA) (Vetter et al., 1999). CPD accumulation in a suite of invertebrate macrozooplankton collected from surface waters off the Antarctic Peninsula was low, ranging from 4 to 6 CPDs Mb −1 DNA (Malloy et al., 1997), in contrast to more recent studies on planktonic embryos of the sea urchin Sterechinus neumayeri that accumulated up to 272 Mb −1 DNA (Karentz et al., 2004) (Table 2). Experiments in the Antarctic with embryos of the ice fish Chaenocephalus aceratus showed that CPD formation was significantly correlated with the cumulative daily dose of UVB (Malloy et al., 1997). Differences in the experimental design of these studies, the phylogenetic affinity of the organisms studied, and their environment make it difficult to generalize these findings in terms of latitudinal differences.

The total accumulated radiation dose as a time integral is of importance, as shown by Lamare et al. (2007). These authors studied the effects of UV-B on the DNA of sea urchin embryos and found that the amount of damage was positively related to the cumulative UV-B dose. Exposure to UVR increased abnormal development associated with both UV-B and UV-A exposure, with rates generally higher in embryos from polar than from temperate regions. The greater sensitivity of Antarctic sea urchin embryos to UVR correlates with their slow metabolism, low concentration of sunscreens, and slow rate of DNA repair compared to temperate and tropical species (Lamare et al., 2007).

div.head: Oxidative stress
div.p: Exposure of natural waters to UVR in the presence of DOM results in the production of hydrogen peroxide and other reactive oxygen species (ROS) that likely mediate some of the damage caused by UVR (Scully et al., 1995). Solar UVR and oxidative stress have both separate and interacting effects on marine organisms. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are formed by the univalent reduction of molecular O 2 owing to spin restrictions on its valence electrons, yielding superoxide radicals (O 2 − ). Further reduction of superoxide leads to the generation of hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) and hydroxyl radicals (HO•) (Asada and Takahashi, 1987). Furthermore, the transfer of absorbed energy to ground state O (photodynamic action) from activated photosensitizers produces highly reactive singlet oxygen (O•). This holds particularly for the UVR band of wavelength (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1999). When UV-B radiation induces the generation of ROS in surface waters, hydrogen peroxide forms and accumulates as a result of DOC photo-activation (Abele and Puntarulo, 2004). ROS naturally originate from the partial reduction of molecular oxygen during aerobic metabolism (DiGuilio et al., 1989). ROS can also be generated from phototoxic chemicals (see below-photosensitization). Uncharged H 2 O 2 induces the formation of highly reactive hydroxyl radicals (OH − ) that induce oxidative damage within cells and tissues. Iron-catalyzed reduction of H O by superoxide anions can further generate the highly reactive hydroxyl radical (OH − ) (Scholz et al., 2008). ROS can damage several important biomolecules, including DNA and proteins (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1999). Oxy-radicals can cause tissue damage through lipid peroxidation chain reactions (Staniek and Nohl, 1999), eventually leading to the impairment of vital cellular functions and alterations of the physicochemical properties of cell membranes (Barata et al., 2005). Lu and Wu (2005a) showed that both UV-A and UV-B cause enhanced production of ROS that subsequently leads to lipid peroxidation (LPO) in sea urchin sperm. Lu and Wu (2005a) provided several explanations for how ROS can damage sea urchin sperm. ROS may directly attack the (single) mitochondrion of sea urchin sperm, initially, resulting in a decrease of membrane potential and, therefore, a reduction in sperm motility and fertilization capacity. Second, ROS may further damage the LPO-damaged plasma membrane. This may affect the ability of sperm to penetrate the egg membrane (DeBaulny et al., 1999), thereby reducing fertilization. Third, UVR may directly damage DNA and protein molecules thereby reducing sperm quality. LPO caused by ROS could result in the loss of fluidity and integrity of sperm membranes, which ultimately interferes with the fusion process during fertilization, as has been shown in mammalian sperm. This has not yet been determined in marine ectotherms (Aitken et al., 1998).

One of the adaptations of Antarctic fish to permanently cold conditions is an elevated content of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in the plasma membrane, which ensures membrane fluidity at low temperatures (Storelli et al., 1998). However, a higher PUFA content may place Antarctic fish at an elevated risk of UVRinduced oxidative stress, because PUFAs are primary targets for ROS. ROS preferentially remove a proton from conjugated double bond systems, creating a peroxyl radical that then initiates lipid peroxidation chain reactions (McCord, 2008). This process is generally described as lipid peroxidation. Vitamin E (␣-tocopherol) is the most powerful lipid soluble antioxidant, and fishes and invertebrates obtain vitamin E from their herbivorous prey that scavenge lipid radicals, thereby preventing the initiation of radical chain reactions (Yamamoto et al., 2001). High lipid stores are also typical for carnivorous invertebrates exposed to direct and indirect radiation damage (Obermüller et al., 2005).

div.head: Phototoxicity
div.p: UVR can have direct effects on biological macromolecules, including DNA, by photosensitization, or indirect effects on macromolecules by photomodification (Lampi et al., 2005). Photosensitization generally leads to the production of singlet oxygen or other ROS that are highly damaging to biomolecules (Chen et al., 2006). Photomodification results in the formation of new compounds that exhibit greater toxicity than the parent phototoxicant (Brack et al., 2003).

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are examples of phototoxic compounds. PAHs are brought into the environment through various pathways, such as atmospheric precipitation, seepages, spills, and industrial and municipal wastewater. PAHs are generally not toxic below their water soluble concentration, but even at these concentrations, they may become highly toxic through photoreactivation by UVR due to their ability to absorb energy in the UV spectrum. The energy associated with these excited PAH molecule states is released by non-radiative pathways as superoxide anions and hydroxyl radicals (Brack et al., 2003).

div.head: UVR-induced tissue damage and apoptosis
div.p: UVR-induced sunburn in fish has been reported for several species, including rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), juvenile plaice (Pleuronectes platessa), and the paddlefish (Polyodon spathula) (references in Zagarese and Williamson, 2000). Sunburn may cause outbreaks of infectious diseases. Fungal infections occur preferentially in fish that have been exposed to excessive sunlight. Handlinger et al. (1997) reported on outbreaks of flexibacteriosis in cultured Atlantic salmon Salmo salar in Tasmania during extended periods of cloud-free days. Effects of UVR on tissues have been performed in very few marine ectotherms. Larvae of the northern anchovy Engraulis mordax showed increased mortality upon UV-B irradiation, while surviving larvae were characterized by brain and eye lesions, retarded growth, and delayed development (Hunter et al., 1979(Hunter et al., , 1981.

If the cellular damage is beyond the organism's ability to repair, then the only solution may be to destroy the damaged cell. Apoptosis, the most common form of programmed cell death in metazoans, is essential for the destruction of damaged or abnormal cells. Involved are probably multiple signaling pathways that converge upstream of a common sequence of events to activate the death program (Fig. 2).

Apoptosis in response to UVR has been reported from several marine organisms (Bonaventura et al., 2005). UVR-induced oxidative stress is known to play a role in apoptosis in sea urchin embryos via activation of cell cycle genes such as p53 and p21 . To date, two apoptotic pathways have been described. These pathways are the death-receptor pathway and the mitochondrial pathway. The mitochondrial pathway is commonly associated with DNA damage and the upregulation or activation of the cell cycle gene p53 (Hengartner, 2000). Exposure to UVR also causes ROS production in the electron transport chain of mitochondria . Both the death receptor and mitochondrial pathways converge at the mitochondria and the Bcl-2 family of genes, where the release of proapoptotic effectors (e.g. cytochrome c, ROS, and caspase 9) occurs (Rich et al., 2000;Vega and Epel, 2004).

div.head: Differential effects of UV-A, UV-B, and UV-C
div.p: The modes of action of UV-A and UV-B differ. Exposure to shorter UV-B wavelengths results in a higher degree of DNA damage, higher levels of oxidative stress, and greater expression of cell cycle genes, all of which promote apoptosis, than exposure to UV-A (Lesser, 2006), which is why most previous studies have concentrated on the damaging effects of UV-B radiation (Adams and Shick, 2001).

UV-A generally causes indirect DNA damage by the formation of chemical intermediates such as oxygen and hydroxyl radicals that interact with DNA to form strand breaks, DNA-protein cross-links, and alkali labile sites (Thoma, 1999). Conversely, UV-B causes direct DNA damage by inducing the formation of cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers and pyrimidine-pyrimidone (6-4) photoproducts. These products can cause mutations or have cytotoxic effects by inhibiting replication or the expression of essential genes (Fig. 2) (Hansen et al., 2003).

UV-A is a powerful prooxidant, inducing both strand breaks and alkali labile sites (Pfeiffer et al., 2005). UV-B, in contrast, produces mainly CPDs (Collins et al., 1997). Single strand breaks are generated transiently, and CPDs can be repaired.

A covariance analysis by Lu and Wu (2005b) in sea urchin sperm showed that the slope of mitochondrial function in relation to UV-A was significantly different from that of UV-B, indicating that they have different effects on mitochondrial function. UV-B is more damaging than UV-A, in that the higher level of ROS induced by UV-B could damage motility and fertilization by impairing sperm membrane integrity. Lu and Wu (2005a) suggested that UV-A caused more lipid peroxidation than UV-B, but was less effective in reducing sperm motility and fertilization in sea urchin sperm.

Experiments on cod embryos by Browman et al. (2000), however, showed a significant effect of UV-B, but not of UV-A, on DNA damage. Vetter et al. (1999) observed diurnal cycling of DNA damage by both UV-B and UV-A, as measured by CPD formation, in experiments with Northern anchovy Engraulis mordax larvae.

Although the impairment of fertilization success caused by UV-A was less marked than that caused by UV-B, Lu and Wu (2005a) suggested that the combined effects of both UV-A and UV-B, rather than UV-B alone, must be considered when assessing the effects and risks of UVR on aquatic animal reproduction.

Previous work on echinoid embryos revealed that UVR had significant effects on cell division, development, morphology, and DNA damage (Akimoto and Shiroya, 1987). Most experimental studies were actually done on echinoderm soma and reproductive cells-being our reason to summarize the results in Table 1. All these studies used artificial light sources that contain germicidal UV-C (254 nm) radiation that is not ecologically relevant, because UVR below 290 nm commonly does not reach sea level. Use of this artificial UV-C light causes significant DNA damage, as indicated by the biological weighting function for DNA damage introduced by Setlow (1974).

Responses to all waveband caused UVR damage include DNA editing and repair . Cells damaged by UVR and oxidative stress can survive, but often remain in the G1-phase of the cell cycle for longer periods of time than normal cells, and may even remain in a permanent state of cellular growth arrest (Evan and Littlewood, 1998).

div.head: Responses to UVR
div.p: Organisms that live in subsurface regions of the Earth such as deep oceans, caves, and other habitats that exclude solar radi-ation, are protected from UVR. Sun-exposed life forms can use four general strategies to cope with the hazards of UVR: behavioral avoidance of UVR exposure, acquisition of sunscreens, repair of UVR-induced damage to macromolecules such as proteins and DNA, and/or elimination of toxic compounds created by UVR exposure ( Fig. 1).

Because repair processes can never be completely efficient, the less damage occurs, the greater the potential advantage to the organism, regardless of the absolute levels of repair that an organism may be able to elicit. Therefore, avoidance and photoprotective mechanisms are of great importance in overall UVR protection. We do not deal with behavioral avoidance strategies in this review, because they are not directly linked to molecular mechanisms.

div.head: Photoprotective pigments
div.p: Mechanisms that passively screen UVR contribute significantly to preventing UVR-induced damage in organisms exposed to UVR for substantial parts of their life-cycles such as photoautotrophic organisms that use sunlight as an energy source. Screening of UVR may also provide some energetic advantage by reducing the energy expenditure required for active avoidance and repair processes.

Several photoprotective compounds found in aquatic organisms are known to directly or indirectly absorb solar UVR (Cockell and Knowland, 1999;Auerswald et al., 2008). Sunscreening metabolites and pigments such as MAAs and carotenoids and those that absorb UV-photons are widely distributed among aquatic organisms (Dahms et al., 2006b;Sommaruga et al., 2006). Sunscreens can be incorporated into cuticles (Schiedt et al., 1993) and other tissues (Newman et al., 2000). These sunscreens absorb UVR efficiently in the range between 309 and 360 nm and dissipate energy thermally without showing fluorescence or generating oxygen radicals (Shick et al., 1995).

A positive correlation between the concentration of MAAs and the tolerance of UVR exposure has been reported for several groups of aquatic organisms (Cockell and Knowland, 1999). As MAAs can only be synthesized by microorganisms that have an active metabolic shikimate pathway, animals can only obtain these compounds from their diet (Riemer et al., 2007) or their zooxanthellate symbionts. Many shallow water invertebrates in tropical to temperate regions, such as corals, maintain microbial symbionts (Dove, 2004).

The dominant MAA in various marine organisms, mycosporine glycine (MG), has a moderate antioxidant potential (Dunlap and Shick, 1998;Kim et al., 2001). UVR-induced developmental abnormalities in sea urchin embryos and larvae decrease with increasing MAA concentrations (Adams and Shick, 1996), and this is correlated with a reduction in CPD formation (Adams and Shick, 2001). MAA concentrations in corals are dependent on their exposure to solar radiation and their occurrence with depth (reviewed by Dunlap and Shick, 1998). These authors showed that in symbiotic associations between microbes and corals, MAAs are probably produced by symbiotic dinoflagellates and are then concentrated in the external tissues of the host, where they protect both partners from UVR damage. Marine invertebrates and fish lacking a photosynthetic partner can still acquire such compounds in high concentrations via their diet (Obermüller et al., 2005). Dunlap and Shick (1998) found high levels of MAAs in bottom-living sea cucumbers that feed on MAA-producing algae and cyanobacteria. They found compounds concentrated in epidermal tissues-as would be expected for a functional UV screen-and in the digestive tract, suggesting a dietary origin.

The extracts of fish eggs collected from natural habitats often show absorbance peaks in the lower range of the UV-A spectrum, suggesting the presence of MAAs (Zagarese and Williamson, 2000). The dominant MAA in cod larvae is MG, an MAA known to have antioxidant activity and to be consumed during reactions with ROS (Dunlap and Yamamoto, 1995). Interestingly, Ben-Yosef et al. (2008) demonstrated that concentrations of the MAA-like substance palythine measured in various life stages of the soft coral Heteroxenia fuscescens were linearly correlated with the ambient temperature. This demonstrates that UVR and temperature can act synergistically.

Carotenoids are ubiquitous in marine organisms such as copepods (Mathews-Roth, 1997). They can photoprotect through two mechanisms: acting as UV-R absorbing sunscreens and protecting proteins, lipids, and DNA against reactive oxygen species (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1999). Carotenoids prevent lipid peroxidation caused by singlet oxygen (O • ), and possibly other reactive oxygen species (Edge et al., 1997) by absorbing the excited energy of these agents into the carotenoid chain, leading to its subsequent degradation. Carotenoids are therefore strong antioxidants and active quenchers of singlet oxygen (Montenegro et al., 2002). This leads to radical chain-breaking antioxidant activity in lipid-rich membranes and tissues (Lamare and Hoffman, 2004).

div.head: UVR and antioxidant defense in marine ectotherms
div.p: The balance between prooxidant situations and antioxidant defenses is essential to prevent oxyradical cellular toxicity, because oxidative damage (i.e. lipid peroxidation and DNA alterations) will occur when the overall antioxidant capacity is exceeded by the generation of ROS (Winston and DiGiulio, 1991). Antioxidant defenses consist of various low molecular-weight free radical scavengers (e.g. glutathione) and a number of specific enzymes, such as superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (see below-antioxidant defenses).

Oxidative stress prevails if oxygen radicals are not controlled by an antioxidant defense system (Abele and Puntarulo, 2004). Regoli et al. (2002) used a total oxyradical scavenging capacity (TOSC) assay to obtain integrative information on the susceptibility of organisms to oxidative stress. This assay also allows discrimination of an organism's ability to deal with different ROS (e.g. ROO − , − OH and HOONO radicals). Artificial exposure of the Arctic scallop (Adamussium colbecki) to UV-A and UV-B radiation resulted in a significant decrease in TOSC values towards peroxyl and hydroxyl radicals (Regoli et al., 2000a). Elevated TOSC levels and antioxidant enzymes for north and south polar bivalves, compared to Mediterranean bivalves, suggests that cold-adapted marine organisms experience high prooxidant forces associated with UVR (Regoli et al., 2000a,b). The induction of antioxidant responses by UVR (both UV-A and UV-B) has also been reported in sea anemones (Shick et al., 1991), corals (Shick et al., 1995), sea urchin embryos , and fish larvae (Lesser et al., 2001). Differences in antioxidant defense abilities also appear to play a critical role in UV-B-induced apoptosis (Shindo and Hashimoto, 1998) (Fig. 2). Camus and Gulliksen (2005) measured TOSC in the cytosolic fraction of the digestive gland and in the cell-free hemolymph of three amphipod species. The authors found significantly low TOSC towards peroxyl and peroxynitrite radicals in the deep-water species Eurythenes grillus compared with the shallow-water species Anonyx nugax, which they attributed to the slower metabolism of the deep-water species. Another species, Gammarus wilkitzkii, was found to have a mechanism that prevents the diffusion of exogenous ROS through the gills and allows excretion of internal H 2 O 2 through the gills to the environment (Camus and Gulliksen, 2005).

div.head: Antioxidant compounds
div.p: To counteract the harmful effects of ROS, living cells contain various low molecular-weight free radical scavengers (e.g. glutathione), including antioxidant enzymes like superoxide dis-mutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione-S-transferase (GST), and glutathione peroxidase (Gpx). These enzymes function in cellular defense against UVR-induced oxidative stress and can also be used as biomarkers of oxidative stress (Sarkar, 2006). GSH plays a critical role in cellular defense against both UV-A and UV-B radiation (Raissudin et al., 2007). If these antioxidant defense mechanisms are not successful, cells will either die (by apoptosis or necrosis), or carcinogenesis will either be initiated or accelerated (Mukhopadhyay et al., 2003). Antioxidative compounds such as flavonoids, carotenoids, and vitamins (e.g. ␣-tocopherol, ascorbate) can be derived from the animal's diet (Obermüller et al., 2005). SOD, which converts H 2 S − to H 2 O 2 , and catalase, which converts H 2 O 2 to water, are present in marine invertebrates (Viarengo et al., 1998). Other smaller ROS scavengers (vitamin C, E, glutathione, and other redox active thiols) function as free-radical chain breaking agents and singlet oxygen (O • ) quenchers (Abele and Puntarulo, 2004). Qin et al. (2008) showed that in human keratinocytes, SOD expression increased upon exposure to UVR, indicating an increase in superoxide radicals and other forms of ROS. CAT appeared more susceptible to photoinactivation than SOD in two marine carnivorous amphipod species studied by Obermüller et al. (2005).

div.head: Cell cycle checkpoint genes p53 and p21 and their role in UVR damage
div.p: The cell cycle checkpoint genes p53 and p21 allow a multicellular organism to repair or destroy cells exposed to agents that cause DNA damage (Bunz et al., 1998). The principal function of p53 is to promote survival or death of cells exposed to agents that cause DNA damage, such as hypoxia, UVR, ROS, or other mutagens (Renzing et al., 1996).

Non-UVR stressors include hypoxia or mutagens produced by ROS (Renzing et al., 1996). Sea urchin embryos and larvae have been shown to possess a functional apoptotic pathway (Voronina and Wessel, 2001;Roccheri et al., 2002). TUNEL assay results have been strongly supported by differential expression of genes for cell cycle and antioxidant proteins . Additionally, in these and other studies , the abnormal morphologies of sea urchin larvae (e.g. 'packed' blastula, blebbing, and exogastrulation) are consistent with the pattern of apoptosis induced by UVR.

Embryos of the green sea urchin S. droebachiensis exposed to UVR show evidence of the direct effects of UVR on DNA, namely the accumulation of CPD photoproducts, and show evidence of apoptosis (positive TUNEL assay results), which indicates the occurrence of DNA strand breaks caused by ROS (Lesser, 2006) (Table 1). In sea urchin embryos, a tight coupling between p53 and p21 expression, which is functionally related to the delay in cell division, is seen shortly after DNA damage (Adams and Shick, 2001;Lesser, 2006). Additionally, the cell cycle regulatory enzyme cdc2 decreases in concentration with increasing exposure to UVR in young sea urchin embryos. We interpret this to be a consequence of the UVR-induced expression of p53 and p21. Inactivation of cdc2 has also been shown to facilitate apoptosis induced by DNA damage (Ongkeko et al., 1995).

Oxidative stress is known to play a role in apoptosis or programmed cell death by activation of p53. Exposure to UVR results in the production of ROS, damage to DNA, activation (=up-regulation) of the p53 pathway, and the arrest of cell division in the G1-phase. Activation of the p53 pathway allows affected cells to undergo DNA editing and repair while being arrested in the G1-phase, followed either by apoptosis or by normal cell division (Renzing et al., 1996). Damaged cells can be repaired and survive, but often remain in the G1-phase of the cell cycle for long periods, or can even have permanently arrested development (Evan and Littlewood, 1998). The expression of p53 in cod larvae increases significantly after exposure to UVR and oxidative stress, resulting in apoptosis, and potentially the death of the developing embryo. The enhanced expression of p53 not only delays cell division and the total number of cells a larva may have, but also decreases the amount of time that G1-arrested and repaired cells have to grow in the context of a temporally-fixed developmental program. Activation of the p53 pathway, if it does not lead to apoptosis and larval mortality, may therefore result in smaller size at hatching as observed for cod larvae exposed to UVR (Lesser et al., 2001). For those larvae that survive the effects of UVR at the biochemical and molecular levels, there is an energetic cost at the organismal level. The sublethal energetic costs of repairing DNA damage or responding to oxidative stress may result in poor growth performance (Lesser et al., 2001). The small (but significant) decrease in size at hatching observed in these experiments may result in a longer planktonic persistance of these fish, and increase the probability of death due to predation.

div.head: Heat shock proteins
div.p: Cells respond to stressful conditions, such as exposure to elevated temperatures, xenobiotics, heavy metals, free radicals, and UVR, by synthesizing a suite of proteins known as heat shock proteins (HSPs). Stress protein synthesis is one of the defense mechanisms activated in a cell after exposure to environmental stressors in ectotherms (Sarkar, 2006). HSPs were originally thought to function primarily as molecular chaperones to facilitate correct protein folding/refolding of non-functional proteins (Kiang and Tsokos, 1998), and are now acknowledged as highly responsive sensors of cell stress in many systems (Bierkens, 2000). Nevertheless, only hsp70 has been studied in marine ectotherms exposed to UVR.

Sea urchins are among the best studied invertebrates in this respect and we summarized the results in Table 1. Matranga et al. (2006) found that hsp70 was upregulated in sea urchin coelomocytes as early as 1 h after irradiation. The authors observed a peak at 1000 J/m 2 corresponding to a 3.4-fold increase in hsp70 levels compared to control coelomocytes (Table 1), suggesting that hsp70 is a sensitive indicator of UV-B stress. Bonaventura et al. (2006) found a dose-dependent increase in hsp70 protein levels in embryos of the sea urchin P. lividus exposed to different UV-B doses. Conversely, little variation was detected in the transcript levels of hsp70 for any of the doses tested, which indicates post-transcriptional regulation of the UV-B induced stress response. The increase in hsp70 levels and p38 MAPK activation has been shown to be dose-dependent in sea urchin embryo UVR experiments (Bonaventura et al., 2005). In general, although the effects of UV-B on hsp70 induction are well documented (Trautinger et al., 1996), very little is known about the mechanisms, threshold levels, and time-courses of UV-B induced hsp70 gene expression in marine ectotherms.

div.head: Mitochondria
div.p: Mitochondria are thought to consume over 90% of the cellular oxygen in unstressed cells and are major sites of cellular ROS production (Han et al., 2001). In vitro, the mitochondrial electron transport chains convert around 2% of the oxygen consumed to univalently reduced superoxide anions; however, the extent to which this happens in vivo and the rate of radical transfer to the cytoplasm is still not clear (St-Pierre et al., 2002). Lu and Wu (2005a) showed that the mitochondria of sea urchin sperm (Antocidaris crassispina) were impaired by environmentally relevant levels of UV-A and UV-B in a dose-dependent manner. However, the membrane integrity of the sperm was impaired only by environmentally relevant levels of UV-B radiation, suggesting that UVR-induced ROS could decrease sperm motility and fertil-ity by damaging mitochondria, thereby reducing the ability of the sperm membrane to fuse with that of the egg (DeBaulny et al., 1999).

Mitochondrial function may provide a reliable predictor of fertilization success of sperm, thereby representing a cost-effective, sensitive, and meaningful bioindicator of fertilization success in fish and aquatic invertebrates (Lu and Wu, 2005b). Dual fluorescent staining with rhodamine 123 (Rh123) and propidium iodide (PI) combined with flow cytometric analysis allowed the simultaneous determination of mitochondrial function and membrane integrity of sperm in the green sea urchin S. droebachiensis (Adams and Shick, 1996) and the catfish Siluris glanis (DeBaulny et al., 1999). Due to the negative potential of the inner membrane, Rh123 accumulates only in functional mitochondria, causing the mitochondria to fluoresce green (Lu and Wu, 2005a).

div.head: Repair of UVR-induced DNA damage in aquatic ectotherms
div.p: The last line of defense against UVR is to repair the damage caused by UVR exposure. The most common type of DNA damage induced by UVR (UV-A and UV-B) is the formation of CPDs and pyrimidine (6-4) pyrimidone photoproducts. These lesions prevent DNA replication and transcription and have mutagenic, teratogenic, or lethal effects. Common repair mechanisms include photoreactivation, nucleotide excision of dimers, recombinational filling of gaps, and resynthesis of DNA (Vetter et al., 1999). DNA repair by photolyase in the presence of light (photoreactivation) and nucleotide excision repair (NER) are the major pathways used to remove UV-induced DNA lesions from the genome to prevent mutagenesis and cell death.

Because the packaging of eukaryotic DNA in nucleosomes and higher order chromatin structures affects DNA structure and accessibility, damage formation and repair are intimately coupled to the structural and dynamic properties of chromatin (Thoma, 1999). Nucleotide excision repair is a more complex repair process that requires damage recognition, incision of the DNA strand near the site of the lesion, the excision and resynthesis of the DNA around the damaged site, and finally, ligation of the single strand after the DNA polymerase detaches (Malloy et al., 1997). NER appears to be universally distributed though it is not thought to be very efficient at repairing CPDs.

Photoenzymatic repair (photoreactivation), which is used to reverse cyclobutane dimers in DNA, relies on the enzymatic activity and energy of photolyase at UV and visible light wavelengths (Schröder et al., 2005). Photolyase activity is widely distributed in nature and photoreactivation has been found in members of all kingdoms, although it is apparently lacking in several species or groups such as mammals (Sancar, 1990). Vetter et al. (1999) showed that true photodependent repair in northern anchovy Engraulis mordax larvae could be stopped by moving samples into the dark. Unhatched embryos that spawned in the dark exhibited a strong photorepair response, suggesting that photolyase expression was innate and not dependent on previous light exposure. Because photorepair relies on wavelengths between UV-A and PAR, laboratory experiments that do not carefully modulate the ratio of UV-B and PAR may overemphasize the effects of UV-B (Day and Neale, 2002). It is unknown whether DNA repair mechanisms are available during early embryogenesis of invertebrates (Vega and Epel, 2004).

DNA repair processes can be slowed down and inhibited at low temperatures as has been shown for the rhodophyte Palmaria palmata (Pakker et al., 2000), which might imply that higher damage levels would be expected in organisms that are exposed to seasonal-(winter), geographical-(polar regions), or depthrelated (deep sea) lower temperatures. However, there is as yet no experimental evidence for the slowing-down of repair processes according to temperature in invertebrates or fish. Lamare et al. (2006), who investigated the photoreactivation repair of CPDs in three echinoid species, suggested that the rate of repair of CPDs is influenced by life history and environment rather than phylogeny. Similarly, Malloy et al. (1997) concluded that the DNA repair capacity of Antarctic organisms (copepods and fishes) depends on environmental conditions such as ambient UVR and the position of the early life stages in the water column, rather than on phylogenetic relationships.

div.head: UVR in ecotoxicology and environmental genomics of marine ectotherms
div.p: 6.1. Ecotoxicology UVR ecotoxicity tests in marine ectotherms have investigated the effects of UVR on acute toxicity by measuring mortality (Kouwenberg et al., 1999), the effects of UVR on partial and full lifecycles by investigating laboratory cohorts (Browman et al., 2003a), and suborganismal endpoints based on short-term UVR exposure . Toxicological test endpoints include measurements of hatching success (Bass and Sistrun, 1997), larval development ratio (Ban et al., 2007;Dahms and Hellio, 2009), feeding ratio (Lacuna and Uye, 2000), and egg production (Lacuna and Uye, 2000). Whole-organism level endpoints such as mortality and reproduction are important for understanding the potential ecological effects of stressors. Molecular endpoints are indispensible for gaining insight into the underlying mechanisms responsible for the observed effects of exposure to UVR. A limited number of studies have employed a multilevel biomarker approach or have described oxidative stress as a potential mediator of the toxic effects of UVR (Pelletier et al., 2006).

The consideration of several toxicological endpoints is promising, because it allows to monitor different aspects of UVR toxicity (Viarengo et al., 2007). The feasibility of measuring the molecular effects of UVR exposure has been demonstrated in a marine copepod (reviewed in Raissudin et al., 2007), in addition to several other marine ectotherms (Abele and Puntarulo, 2004). A study on the toxic effects of simultaneous exposure to UVR and watersoluble contaminants indicated that these stressors can act either additively or synergistically in various organisms, such as invertebrates and fish (Pelletier et al., 2006). Laboratory tests that consider only a single species, or use artificial UV bulbs that produce environmentally unrealistic wavelengths or spectral compositions of light are, therefore, of little environmental relevance (Dahms and Hellio, 2009).

div.head: Environmental genomics
div.p: Identification of genes that are differentially expressed as a result of exposure to UVR could greatly enhance our ability to understand the modes of toxicity of UVR and allow the identification of novel biomarkers of UVR damage (Bonaventura et al., 2006;Hofmann and Place, 2007). Given that molecular biomarkers can provide early warnings of adverse environmental effects, genomic biomarker responses are particularly useful for UVR response studies in the upper water column and in coastal marine systems (Clark et al., 2004). However, biomarker information needs to be more specific to allow discrimination between UVR and other stressors (Hofmann et al., 2005;Wilson et al., 2005). Sequence information from several functional genes involved in the UVR stress response, as well as expressed sequence tag (EST) data and mitochondrial information could provide a varied suite of genomic biomarkers for future environmental genomic studies that specifically investigate the effects of organismal exposure to UVR.

div.head: Perspectives
div.p: We expect ecophysiological and toxicogenomic studies to become increasingly important in UVR research because they can elucidate the ultimate causes of UVR damage as well as the cellular responses, while at the same time accounting for various levels of integration (age-and gender-specific levels, populations, communities, ecosystems). Molecular approaches can be used to determine UVR exposure much earlier than physiological measurements. Knowledge of genomic and proteomic responses to environmental stressors like UVR will allow for more specific approaches. In addition, collaborations between several key laboratories will allow more integrated multinational studies that can pursue molecular comparisons at ecosystem scale.

Reasonable interpretations of gene expression will only be possible when UVR experiments are conducted as part of an integrated design to understand the responses observed at the physiological and proteomic levels. Gene expression studies under different stresses will allow discrimination between common and specific functions, and indicate how these different stresses are linked. Overlap of genetic responses may allow the organism to respond more efficiently to multiple stressors. Determination of the expression profiles of specific genes will provide fundamental insights into how these responses vary according to ontogenetic stage, gender, phylogeny, and environment. As yet, however, only universal bioindicators for stress are employed in UVR studies, and these provide limited information about the mechanisms of UVR action. More specific endpoints of UVRgenotoxicity should be determined by screening various gene expression profiles related only to UVR damage. The sensitivity of organisms to UVR has been shown to relate to differences in the efficiency of their protective mechanisms and repair systems. A better understanding of such mechanisms will allow the development of technologies to monitor and address the adverse impacts of UVR.

Furthermore, it is critical to identify interactions between multiple stressors and UVR, because the combined effects are turning out to be astonishingly complex and could include abiotic interactions in addition to biodegradation and bioactivation of chemicals by UVR. Studies that do not consider biologically relevant irradiance levels that organisms encounter in their natural environment (UV-C and UV-B in particular) provide little useful information. Extrapolation of laboratory results from single species or unrealistic intensities of contaminants with artificial UV lamps is problematic, because interspecific interactions, self-protective behavior, and chemical interactions with naturally occurring organic matter are not accounted for. Results from both, laboratory and field studies should be interpreted cautiously because both approaches can be affected by confounding factors, precluding the interpretation of UVR-specific effects.
